enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: OPIM 3103; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

description: Classroom course in special topics in operations management, operations research and information management as announced in advance for each semester.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: OPIM 3103 and others as announced separately for each offering; open to juniors or higher.

description: Individual study of special topics in operations management, operations research and information management as mutually arranged between a student and an instructor.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

description: Students are expected to develop their own plan for a research project, conduct the research, and write-up this research, consulting periodically with a faculty member.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to juniors or higher; open only to OPIM Department Honors Students with consent of the instructor.

course name: Senior Thesis in Operations and Information Management
description: Enrollment Requirements: OPIM 4996; open only to OPIM Department Honors Students with consent of instructor and Department Head; open to juniors or higher.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: OPIM 4996; open only to OPIM Department Honors Students with consent of instructor and Department Head; open to juniors or higher.

course name: One Health: People, Animals, Plants, and the Environment
description: Exploration of health concepts and ecosystems where people, animals, plants, and the environment interconnect and impact each other. CA 3.
enrollment requirements: Skill Codes: COMP: Environmental Literacy

description: Hands-on, basic biomedical research laboratory techniques with an emphasis on chemical and biological safety, as well as laboratory proficiency.

course name: Health and Disease Management of Animals
description: Designed for students who plan to own and work with domestic animals. Its purpose is to develop student competence in disease management and to foster an intelligent working relationship with their veterinarian. The course will cover a systematic study of infectious and noninfectious diseases of domestic animals from the standpoint of economy and public health.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

description: Fundamental biology of medically relevant viruses and parasites including host-pathogen interactions and microbiological laboratory techniques.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

description: Majors may take this course in each semester of the senior year.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

description: Special problems in connection with departmental research programs and diagnostic procedures for diseases of animals. Some suggested topics are histopathologic laboratory procedures, clinical hematology, diagnostic bacteriology, diagnostic parasitology.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Principles of basic and clinical immunobiology; phylogeny and ontogeny of the immune response, characteristics of the immune response, cellular and humoral immunity; central and peripheral lymphoid tissues; mechanisms of immunologic injury and immunologic diseases; comparative and veterinary immunology; transplantation and tumor immunology.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

course name: Diagnostic Techniques for the Biomedical Sciences
description: Theoretical basis and practical exposure to modern laboratory methods used in the biomedical sciences for disease diagnosis.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

description: Mechanisms of emergence that different pathogens have used to cause disease in new hosts.

Organ-based study of human and animal diseases. Use of gross, microscopic, and physiologic evidence to diagnose disease. Topics covered include central nervous, skin, hepatobiliary, endocrine, and digestive systems.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: Previous coursework in Cell Biology. PATH 3810 and PATH 3820 can be taken in any order.

description: Inquiry-based laboratory course on systems pathophysiology, using gross, microscopic, and physiologic evidence to diagnose diseases of the central nervous, skin, hepatobiliary, endocrine, and digestive systems.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PATH 3820, which may be taken concurrently.

description: Investigation of chronic and inflammatory diseases like asthma, arthritis, and cancer, enabling students to identify risk factors, describe disease mechanisms, and design diagnostic and therapeutic treatment plans that address socioeconomic, cultural, and access-related factors.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: A course in physiology such as PATH 2100, or PATH 3810, or PATH 3820, or PNB 2250, or PNB 2264-2265, or PNB 2774 - PNB 2776, or equivalent.

course name: Bioinformatics in Molecular Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases
description: Basic concepts and terminologies in bioinformatics and infectious disease epidemiology. Hands-on, practical experiences in sequence analysis: database, alignment, phylogenetic analysis, and visualization of data.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ANSC 3121, MCB 2400, or MCB 2410.

description: Writing of Honors thesis based on an independent research project in Pathobiology.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open only to Honors students; instructor consent required.

description: Students develop an understanding of approaches for scientists and engineers to use the immune system to combat infectious and chronic diseases. Both traditional and modern molecular approaches to vaccine and immunotherapy design will be discussed. Students will gain an appreciation for the transition from basic research to practical applications.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: Previous coursework in Immunology or equivalent.

description: Human and environmental health issues and problems associated with voluntary and involuntary exposure to toxic chemicals. Toxic chemical risks as compared to other societal health risks, the processes of scientific risk assessment, how environmental and human exposure to toxic chemicals are interdependent, and the social and environmental management of toxic chemical risks. CA 3.
enrollment requirements: Skill Codes: COMP: Environmental Literacy

description: Bridges the gap between traditional undergraduate curricula in chemistry and biology through the interdisciplinary topic of chemical biology. Fundamental topics in chemistry are reviewed and explained within the context of biological environments. Introduction to current state-of-the art techniques and methods used in chemical biology research. Analysis and interpretation of data from chemical biology experiments and use this information to generate scientific conclusions.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: CHEM 1128Q or CHEM 1148Q, and BIOL 1107.

description: (Also offered as PHRX 3097W.)
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open only to honors students within the School of Pharmacy with consent of the instructor and Associate Dean.

description: (Also offered as PHRX 3099.) Designed primarily for qualified students who wish to extend their knowledge in the various fields represented in the School of Pharmacy. A divisional and pharmacy cumulative grade point average of 2.8 or above is normally required for enrollment. A written summary of work performed is required at the end of each semester.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: This course establishes the essentials in pharmacotherapy concepts and serves as the foundation for future therapeutics modules. It provides an introduction to medication therapy considerations across the lifespan (pediatric, pregnancy and lactation, geriatrics).
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 3004, PHRX 3005, PHRX 3030, PHRX 3010.

description: Develop and demonstrate the breadth of knowledge in the foundational sciences associated with cardiovascular patient care. Apply foundational knowledge in prevention and/or treatment of commonly encountered cardiovascular disease states.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 3004, PHRX 3005, PHRX 3030.

description: This course will provide an understanding of the basic principles of thermodynamics, ionic equilibrium, chemical kinetics and diffusion; application of these principles to formulation, stability and dissolution of a drug product, and drug release from the dosage form for optimum therapeutic outcome.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 3030

description: This course focuses on compounding techniques and standards used in preparing pharmaceutical dosage forms that are not required to be sterile.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 3061

description: This course provides students with a fundamental understanding of public health, health policy, and population health. Students will draw connections between pharmacy and public health and explore ways in which pharmacists can aid in solving our nation's health problems.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Must have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

description: Students will read a popular leadership book and participate in activities focused on its content. Discussion posts, study guides and participation in in-class discussions. Applications to fundamental principles to pharmacy practice. Culminates with a discussion with the author or other leadership expert. This course can be repeated for credit because each year will focus on a new book.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to students in the pharmacy program.

description: A broad overview of leadership development, appreciation of personal strengths, and professional development. Run in collaboration with the University's Office of Leadership Programs, with the school's Phi Lambda Sigma members serving as mentors.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to first year Pharmacy students.

description: This course will apply the pharmacist’s patient care process to introductory community and ambulatory practice.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 3008, PHRX 3010, PHRX 3062.

description: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to students in the pharmacy program.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to students in the pharmacy program.

description: (Also offered as PHAR 3097W.)
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open only to honors students within the School of Pharmacy with consent of the instructor and Associate Dean.

description: (Also offered as PHAR 3099.) Designed primarily for qualified students who wish to extend their knowledge in the various fields represented in the School of Pharmacy. A divisional and pharmacy cumulative grade point average of 2.8 or above is normally required for enrollment. A written summary of work performed is required at the end of each semester.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to students in the pharmacy program.

description: Application of pharmacoeconomic principles to formulary management, health-related quality of life, cost-benefit analysis, and pharmacoeconomic literature analysis.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ECON 1201; PHRX 4050; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy .

description: Presentation of a specific sub area of pharmacy with focus on biological, chemical, clinical/therapeutic, sociological or legal/ethical aspects of drugs, dosage forms or health care systems to improve the student's writing, presentation, and discussion skills.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 3006, 3007 and 3008; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to gastroenterological drug therapy management.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 4040 and 4041; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to endocrinologic drug therapy management.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 4040 and 4041; open only School of Pharmacy students. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 5052.

description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to dermatologic drug therapy management.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 4041; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

description: Advanced techniques and knowledge in prescription compounding will be applied to the preparation of extemporaneously prepared dosage forms that meet the needs of individual patients.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 4031; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

description: An interprofessional program designed to develop future health professionals dedicated to caring for urban underserved populations and working in interprofessional teams. Open to UConn Urban Health Scholars only.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to UConn Urban Health Scholars.

course name: Follow the Money: Impact of Payment Reform and Health Policy on Pharmacy Practice
description: Introductory course on the impact of health care delivery and payment reform on new practice opportunities for pharmacists. Topics include patient-centered medical homes, accountable care organizations, community health teams, population health, medication therapy management, value-based insurance design, and new reimbursement models to support pharmacists in direct patient care roles. A holistic view of these topics is examined from the consumer/patient, health care professional, payor, and health-system perspectives.

Second in a two-semester sequence for students in the LEADERS Track. Provides an introduction to effective leadership through an exploration of leadership styles and concepts and their application to various opportunities and challenges in pharmacy.

Introduction to healthcare ethics, engages students with an interest in treating patients in case-study practice scenarios allowing them to develop a working knowledge of ethical principles and render patient care decisions based upon ethical reasoning. Introduces ethical concepts and professional codes of ethics, and discusses the application of these concepts to contemporary examples of health care scenarios. Introduces the history of American healthcare, exploring the period from our nation's founding to the present. Introduces the theories of health and disease that have changed over time as has the role of healthcare professionals and the pharmaceutical industry.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to students in the School of Pharmacy. Recommended preparation: PHRX 3050.

description: Reinforces the use of the pharmacists' patient care process and interprofessional practice competencies. Reinforcing and applying skills learned in previous courses. Develops patient care skills including assessment of patient medication regimens of increasing complexity and diabetes device education for patients. Students will prepare to engage with pharmacy medication distribution processes, pharmacy informatics processes, patient safety, and professional networking. These activities will be applied in IPPE (Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experiences) at selected institutional pharmacy practice sites.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHRX 4020 or 4063; open to seniors in the School of Pharmacy.

description: Topics may include skepticism, proofs of God, knowledge of the external world, induction, free-will, the problem of evil, miracles, liberty and equality. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities

description: Techniques for evaluating inductive and deductive arguments; applications to specific arguments about philosophical topics, for example the mind-body problem or free will vs. determinism. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities

description: Discussion of selections from such philosophers as Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, and Hume. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities

description: Topics may include the nature of the good life, the relation between social morality and individual rights, and practical moral dilemmas. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities

description: Classic non-Western texts on such problems as the nature of reality and of our knowledge of it, and the proper requirements of social ethics, along with comparison to classic Western approaches to the same problems. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities, CA4INT: Div & Multi - Intl

description: Topics concern social ethics and gender, such as gender equality and the impact of gender norms on individual freedom. Specific topics are examined in light of the intersections between gender and race, ethnicity, class, and sexual orientation. CA 1. CA 4.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities, CA4: Diversity & Multicultural

description: Philosophical issues raised by humanity’s interaction with its environment. Topics may include ethical and policy ramifications of the use of non-human animals for food, medicine, and scientific inquiry; whether the natural world has a status calling for its protection or preservation; obligations to future generations; environmental justice; and movements such as deep ecology, ecofeminism, and social ecology. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Skill Codes: COMP: Environmental Literacy

description: An exploration of existential philosophy from a global, multicultural perspective. Focus will be on existentialists from the Global South in conversation with those in the Global North. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities, CA4INT: Div & Multi - Intl

description: Theories of ethics, with specific application to ethical issues in modern health care. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities

course name: Bioethics and Human Rights in Cross-Cultural Perspective
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2170W.) Philosophical examination of the ethical and human rights implications of recent advances in the life and biomedical sciences from multiple religious and cultural perspectives. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open to sophomores or higher.

description: Theories of knowledge and justification. Topics may include skepticism, induction, confirmation, perception, memory, testimony, a priori knowledge.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: Systematic analysis of deductive validity; formal languages which mirror the logical structure of portions of English; semantic and syntactic methods of verifying relations of logical consequence for these languages.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: At least one of LING 1010, POLS 1002, or one three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: Judgments of good and evil, right and justice, the moral 'ought' and freedom; what do such judgments mean, is there any evidence for them, and can they be true?
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: Judgments of good and evil, right and justice, the moral 'ought' and freedom; what do such judgments mean, is there any evidence for them, and can they be true?
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

description: Conceptual, ontological, and normative issues in political life and thought; political obligation; collective responsibility; justice; liberty; equality; community; the nature of rights; the nature of law; the justification of punishment; related doctrines of classic and contemporary theorists such as Plato, Rousseau, John Rawls.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: (Also offered as CAMS 3257.) Greek philosophy from its origin in the Pre-Socratics through its influence on early Christianity. Readings from the works of Plato and Aristotle. May include related ancient philosophical traditions.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: Central philosophical issues as discussed by philosophers such as Descartes, Locke, Berkeley, Hume and Kant.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: Philosophical dimensions of problems in contemporary life. Topics vary by semester.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level; open to juniors or higher.

description: Ethical and epistemological questions encountered in collecting, interpreting, inferring from and acting upon data—including when these activities are automated or carried out on large observational data sets. Issues may include data privacy and ownership; informed consent; algorithmic bias, equity, and transparency; the theory-ladenness of data; the logic of scientific inference; corporate and institutional responsibility; and implications for democratic and other social values.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: Ethical questions concerning human interaction with the natural world. Topics may include the moral standing of animals, plants, species, and ecosystems; the value of wilderness and biodiversity; obligations to future generations; environmental racism and justice; ecofeminism and deep ecology; and ethical dimensions of environmental policy.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level.

description: (Also offered as HRTS 3220W.) Ontology and epistemology of human rights investigated through contemporary and/or historical texts. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

description: The nature of law; law's relation to morality; law's relation to social facts; the obligation to obey the law; interpreting texts; spheres of law; international law; the justification of state punishment; the good of law; related doctrines of contemporary theorists such as Herbert Hart and Ronald Dworkin.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level, which may be taken concurrently.

description: The historical, religious, and philosophical development of Asian systems of thought.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level; open to juniors or higher.

description: Basic concepts and applications of physics for the non-science major.  Scientific principles and quantitative relationships involving mechanics, energy, heat and temperature, waves, electricity and magnetism, and the theory of the atom are covered.  A laboratory provides hands-on experience with the principles of physics. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1201 or 1401 or 1501 or 1601.

description: A basic introductory astronomy course including principles of celestial coordinate systems and telescope design; applications of fundamental physical laws to the sun, planets, stars and galaxies; evolution of stars, galaxies and the universe; recent space probe results, modern cosmology, astrobiology. Basic quantitative laboratory techniques relevant to astronomy. Night observing sessions are an integral part of the course. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1020.

description: Concepts of physics applied to current problems of the physical environment: energy, transportation, pollution. No previous knowledge of physics is assumed. Not applicable to any requirement that specifies a course in "general physics." CA 3.
enrollment requirements: Skill Codes: COMP: Quantitative Competency

description: Principles of physics and quantitative reasoning applied to astrobiology, the search for extraterrestrial life, and cosmic, stellar, and atmospheric conditions for habitability. A systems perspective on the impacts of human civilization on habitability. CA 3.
enrollment requirements: Skill Codes: COMP: Environmental Literacy, COMP: Quantitative Competency

description: A non-calculus based course introducing the laws of force and motion applied to mechanical phenomena. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. The laboratory offers fundamental training in precise measurements. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: MATH 1060Q or a qualifying score equivalent to pre-Calculus on the math placement assessment (placement.uconn.edu/mathematics-placement). Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1401Q, 1501Q, or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1202Q.

description: A non-calculus based course introducing the principles governing electromagnetic phenomena, including electromagnetic radiation and waves and electric circuits. The laboratory offers fundamental training in precise measurements. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1201Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1402Q, 1502Q, or 1602Q.

description: Physics problems, emphasizing applications of calculus, dealing with topics in general physics. Intended for those students who have taken or are taking PHYS 1202Q and who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence equivalent to PHYS 1401Q-1402Q or 1501Q-1502Q.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1202Q, and MATH 1122 or 1132Q, any of which may be taken concurrently. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1401Q, 1501Q or 1601Q.

description: Quantitative study of the basic facts and principles of physics with an emphasis on mechanical phenomena. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. The laboratory offers fundamental training in physical measurements. Recommended for non-engineering students who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence. It is also recommended for science majors for whom a one year introductory physics course is adequate. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: MATH 1121Q or 1131Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1501Q or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1402Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, after passing PHYS 1201Q.

description: Quantitative study of the basic facts and principles of physics with an emphasis on electromagnetic phenomena, including electromagnetic radiation and waves and electric circuits. The laboratory offers fundamental training in physical measurements. Recommended for non-engineering students who desire to have a calculus-based physics sequence. It is also recommended for science majors for whom a one year introductory physics course is adequate. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1401Q. Recommended preparation: MATH 1122Q or 1132Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHYS 1502Q or 1602Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, by students who have passed PHYS 1202Q.

description: Introduction to Newton's laws, their extensions and applications. Concepts such as work, mechanical energy, linear and angular momentum, and energy conservation are explained. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Recommended for prospective Engineering majors. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: PHYS 1010Q or high school physics; CE 2110; MATH 2110Q or 2130Q, which may be taken concurrently. Not open for credit after passing PHYS 1401Q or 1601Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing 1502Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with the permission of the instructor, by students who have passed PHYS 1201Q.

description: Introduction to principles of electromagnetism and Maxwell's equations, including electric circuits, electromagnetic wave propagation, optics, and other relevant applications to engineering. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Recommended for prospective Engineering majors. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1501Q. Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1402Q or 1602Q. May be taken for not more than two credits, with instructor's permission, by students who have passed PHYS 1202Q.

description: Foundational principles of mechanics: kinematics, forces, energy, momentum, angular momentum, torque, gravitation, waves, harmonic motion and nonlinear dynamics. Basic concepts of calculus are used. Recommended for prospective Physics majors, this course is taught integrating theory, experimental activities, and collaborative problem solving in an active learning setting. CA 3-LAB.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: MATH 1121Q or 1131Q or 1151Q (1151Q is preferred for physics majors). Not open to students who have passed PHYS 1401Q or 1501Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 1602Q. May be taken for not more than three credits, with instructor's permission, by students who passed PHYS 1201Q.

description: The inadequacies of classical physical concepts in the submicroscopic domain. The revision of physical principles that led to special relativity and modern quantum theory. Application to topics chosen from atomic and molecular physics, solid state physics, nuclear physics and elementary particle physics.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q , which may be taken concurrently; or PHYS 1202 with consent of instructor. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 3300, 3401, 4300, or 4900.

course name: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences
description: Theoretical mathematical methods required for physical science courses.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1230 or PHYS 1402Q or PHYS 1502Q or PHYS 1530 or PHYS 1602Q; and MATH 2110Q; either or both may be taken concurrently; or instructor consent.

description: Experiments in classical and/or quantum phenomena with an emphasis on acquiring, analyzing, and interpreting experimental data. Extensive writing in the style of experimental reports and/or journal articles.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1201Q or 1401Q or 1501Q or 1601Q; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

description: Observational astronomy and applications to astrophysical phenomena. Topics include telescopes and astronomical instrumentation, production of chemical elements and molecules, distance scales, black holes and compact objects, gravitational lensing, galaxy kinematics and structure, dark matter, dark energy, cosmic rays, gravitational waves, and Big Bang cosmology.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 2701. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHYS 4710, 4720, or 4740.

description: Newton's Laws of motion applied to mass points, systems of particles, and rigid bodies.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q; MATH 2110Q or 2130Q which may be taken concurrently.

description: Further applications of Newton's Laws; continuous media; Lagrange's and Hamilton's formulation of dynamics.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: MATH 2410Q or 2420Q; PHYS 3101 or CE 2120.

description: The principles of devices and their applications to instrumentation in science and engineering. Rectification, filtering, regulation, input and output impedance, basic transistor circuits, operational amplifiers, preamplifiers for photodiodes and other transducers, logic gates, and digital circuits.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q or instructor consent.

description: Advanced theory and applications of electrostatics, magnetostatics, potentials, and electromagnetic fields in matter.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q or instructor's consent; MATH 2110Q and 2410Q, or MATH 2130Q and 2420Q.

description: Advanced theory and applications of electromagnetic fields. Gauge transformations, electromagnetic waves and radiation, and relativistic corrections to electrodynamics.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 3201.

description: The laws of thermodynamics and their microscopic statistical basis; entropy, temperature, Boltzmann factor, chemical potential, Gibbs factor, and the distribution functions.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 1230 or 1402Q or 1502Q or 1530 or 1602Q; PHYS 2300; MATH 2110Q and 2410Q, or MATH 2130Q and 2420Q. Recommended preparation: PHYS 3201 and 3401.

description: Elementary Principles of quantum mechanics; solutions to the Schrödinger equation for bound states and scattering in one dimension; general solution for central forces in two and three dimensions, orbital angular momentum and spin, and other fundamental quantum mechanical principles.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 2300; MATH 2110 and 2410 or MATH 2130 and 2420.

description: Applications of quantum mechanics, useful approximation methods, the variational method, the WKB method, scattering and other advanced topics.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 3401.

description: Introduction to original investigation performed by the student under the guidance of a faculty member. The student is required to submit a brief report at the end of each semester.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

description: Research investigation for the advanced undergraduate. Research and writing of a Thesis are required. Final public presentation is recommended.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

description: May be repeated for credit
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Gravity and the problem of motion from the ancient Greeks to Newton to Einstein. Special relativity. General relativity. Curvature. Classic tests of general relativity. Gravitational waves. Black holes. Newtonian cosmology. Big Bang theory. Inflation. Dark matter. Dark energy. Accelerating universe.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 2300, 3101, and 3201; or instructor consent.

description: Basic principles and techniques of observational and computational astrophysics. Statistical techniques for data analysis and interpretation of astronomical data. Data mining, visualization, and numerical techniques in simulations of astrophysical systems. Includes short research projects using data from observations and/or simulations.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PHYS 2701 and PHYS 2702.

course name: Learning by Experiencing and Applying Physiological Principles II
description: Exploration of the role that gene regulation, transcript processing, protein production, and protein function play in the physiology of limb development. Emphasis placed on understanding and communicating primary literature, and experimental systems used in model organisms.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 1201.

description: An introduction to comparative animal physiology, emphasizing the evolutionary impacts of diverse physical, chemical, and environmental factors on vertebrates and invertebrates.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1107. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1108.

description: An introduction to comparative animal physiology, emphasizing the evolutionary impacts of diverse physical, chemical, and environmental factors on vertebrates and invertebrates.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1107; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1108.

description: Fundamentals of human anatomy and physiology, for students in human health and human performance related majors. Topics covered include the cardiovascular, immune, respiratory, digestive, renal, and reproductive systems. May not be counted toward the Biological Sciences or PNB majors.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 2264. Not open to students who have passed PNB 2275. Repeat restrictions apply; see advising.uconn.edu/repeat-policy for information.

course name: Enhanced Human Physiology and Anatomy I
description: Fundamentals of human physiology and anatomy enhanced through discussion. A focus on fundamental cell and membrane physiology, as well as the musculoskeletal, nervous, and endocrine systems.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1107; CHEM 1122 or CHEM 1124Q or CHEM 1127Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed PNB 2264 or PNB 2274. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PNB 2775. Repeat restrictions apply; see advising.uconn.edu/repeat-policy for details.

course name: Enhanced Human Physiology and Anatomy II
description: Fundamentals of human physiology and anatomy enhanced through discussion. A focus on organ systems, including the cardiovascular, respiratory, lymphatic, digestive, renal, and reproductive systems.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 2774. Not open to students who have passed PNB 2265 or PNB 2275. Repeat restrictions apply; see advising.uconn.edu/repeat-policy for information.

course name: Enhanced Human Physiology and Anatomy Laboratory
description: Fundamentals of human physiology and anatomy enhanced through inquiry-based laboratories.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 2775, which may be taken concurrently. Not open to students who have passed PNB 2264, PNB 2265, PNB 2274, or PNB 2275.

course name: Public Communication of Physiology and Neurobiology
description: Strategies for effective public communication of science, focusing on accessibly conveying physiological concepts, and considering the role of life scientists as public communicators. Student work may include storytelling, blogging, data visualization, and videography.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One 2000-level course in PNB; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open only to Physiology and Neurobiology majors.

description: Molecular and cellular techniques used to answer physiology research questions in Drosophila models. Students will gain hands-on laboratory experience measuring lifespan, ovulation, fecundity, tissue remodeling, respiration rate, and metabolic parameters. Assays may include western blotting, immunoprecipitation, immunohistochemistry, spectroscopy, PCR, and mass spectrometry.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 3178; Students with related research experience may enroll with instructor consent. Recommended Preparation: PNB 2275 or 2775 or 2250.

course name: Field Study in Physiology and Neurobiology
description: Supervised field work at an off-campus research organization or business.  Activities that meet objectives consistent with a major in Physiology and Neurobiology must be planned and agreed upon in advance by the job site supervisor, the faculty coordinator and the student. May be repeated for a total of up to 6 credits. One credit may be earned for each 42 hours of pre-approved activities up to a maximum of 4 credits. May be applied towards the major with permission of department head subject to the PNB major's 3-credit research group limitation. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for a total of 6 credits

description: Brain functions, from molecular and cellular to overall central nervous system organization. Topics of current scientific interest.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One 2000 level course in PNB or consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PNB 3253W.

course name: Current Topics in Molecular and Developmental Neurobiology
description: Current topics from primary literature. Molecular mechanisms of brain and nervous system development.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 3251; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open to juniors and seniors only. Recommended preparation: PNB 2274 and 2275 or 2774 and 2775.

description: Anatomy of the human brain and spinal cord; emphasis on the structure and functions of major regions in the central nervous system.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 2264 or 2774; open to juniors or higher.

description: Case study of a disease: genetics and inheritance patterns; molecular defects, including transcription and post-transcription defects; physiological defects; therapeutic approaches.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 2774, MCB 2210 or 2410 or 3010; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open to juniors or higher; instructor consent required.

description: The evolution of hormonal signaling systems in invertebrates and vertebrates.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: A 2000-level course in PNB or instructor consent. Open to juniors or higher.

description: Various neurotransmitter systems in the brain including anatomy, physiology, cell biology and biochemistry. Neurotransmitters, receptors and transporters at synapses. Synaptic signaling pathways and molecules. Meets during the first nine weeks of the semester.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One 2000-level course in PNB or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher. Not open to students who have taken PNB 3276. Recommended preparation: MCB 2000 or 3010.

description: Introductory grounding and experience for students interested in the healing professions in how patients and families experience illness, and what it's like to be a professional health provider.
Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary; Open only to juniors or higher.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary; Open only to juniors or higher.

course name: Undergraduate Research in Physiology and Neurobiology
description: Students may apply up to a maximum of three credits of PNB 3296 or PNB 4296 toward the credits-in-major requirement.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Designed for the advanced undergraduate student who desires to pursue a special problem as an introduction to independent investigation.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms supporting the detection of sensory stimuli in vertebrates, invertebrates and other organisms. Sensory transduction mediating smell, taste, touch, pain, hearing, vision, infrared heat, and electric fields.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PNB 3251 or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.

course name: Honors Undergraduate Research In Physiology and Neurobiology
description: Students may apply up to a maximum of three credits of PNB 3296 or 4296 toward the credits-in-major requirement. Not restricted to students in the Honors program.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to Honors students; instructor consent required.

course name: Senior Research Thesis in Physiology and Neurobiology
description: Special research or independent investigation for advanced undergraduates. Involves research and writing a thesis.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011 or 2011. Three credits of PNB 3296 or 4296, which may be taken concurrently; open to juniors or higher; open only with consent of instructor and departmental honors committee. Not limited to honors students.

course name: The Great American Lawn: History, Culture, and Sustainability
description: Examination of the health, social, cultural, and environmental impacts of the largest irrigated crop in the U.S. CA 2. CA 3. Formerly offered as SPSS 1060.
enrollment requirements: Skill Codes: COMP: Environmental Literacy

description: Science and practice of horticultural plant propagation and culture. Basic concepts of plant structure, growth and function.  Integrated pest management. Impact of new technology. Horticulture and the environment. Formerly offered as SPSS 1110.

Development of agricultural systems and technologies and their influence on societies. Topics include plant and animal domestication, food and industrial crops and centers of production, environmental issues, and agricultural ethics. CA 3. Formerly offered as SPSS 1150.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA3: Science & Technology

description: Introduction to the physical, chemical and biological properties of soils. The relationship between soils and the growth of higher plants. Impact of soils on environmental quality. CA 3. Formerly offered as SPSS 2120.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: CHEM 1122 or CHEM 1124Q or CHEM 1127Q or CHEM 1137Q or CHEM 1147Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PLSC 3620.

description: Soil science laboratory with an emphasis on environmental issues, Analyses of soil physical, biological and chemical properties. Includes weekday and weekend field trips. Formerly offered as SPSS 2125.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PLSC 2120, which may be taken concurrently.

description: Cultural management techniques including soil aeration, topdressing, mowing, thatch removal, grass or species selection, fertilization, irrigation and management of personnel, pests, equipment and inventory. Field trips required. Taught with SAPL 210. Formerly offered as SPSS 2210.

Identification, nomenclature, cultural requirements and landscape uses of herbaceous perennials, ornamental grasses, ferns, annuals and bulbs. Study of live plants is required. Taught with SAPL 430. Formerly offered as SPSS 2430.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Not open for credit to graduate students.

description: Application of ecological processes to modern agricultural production practices. Soil quality and maintenance of soil health and productivity. Ecological management of soils, crops, and livestock systems. Sustainability and enhancement of ecological services within agroecosystems. Taught with SAPL 500. Formerly offered as SPSS 2500E.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: introductory course in plant biology, plant ecology, or environmental science.

description: The study of flower arrangement as an art form with emphasis on historical background, artistic principles, color harmony and care of perishable media. Individual expression is encouraged in the creation of floral composition. Taught with SAPL 520. Formerly offered as SPSS 2520.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: May not be taken out of sequence after passing PLSC 3530 or HORT 3530.

description: Writing as a component of communicating facts and opinions in the theory and practice of Horticulture. Assignments will reflect forms of writing commonly encountered by professional horticulturists, including descriptive brochures, articles for mass media, extension bulletins, and technical manuals. Formerly offered as SPSS 2560W.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open only to Plant Science, Horticulture, or Turfgrass Science majors.

description: Effects of environmental stresses and turfgrass management practices on growth, development, and physiology of turfgrasses. Implementation of proper management practices to promote optimal turfgrass health under stress conditions. Formerly offered as SPSS 3150.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PLSC 1100. Corequisite: PLSC 2120.

description: Scientific, legal, and ethical aspects of Biotechnology application in agriculture, health medicine, forensics, and the environment. Designed for students with diverse departmental affiliations. Formerly offered as SPSS 3230.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA3: Science & Technology

course name: Modern and Traditional Plant Breeding Techniques
description: Hands-on experiments for traditional and modern plant breeding techniques, including artificial crossing/hybridization, polyploidy induction, plant tissue culture and transgenic plant production, and radiation- and genome editing-mediate mutagenesis. Formerly offered as SPSS 3255.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: One of BIOL 1102, 1108, or 1110; or MCB 2410; or PLSC 3210, 3230, 3245 or 4210.

description: The commercial production of small fruits and grapes in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic regions including varieties, fruit-growing systems and pruning, site requirements, harvesting methods, post-harvest requirements, marketing, pest complexes and IPM strategies of the major berry crops. Formerly offered as SPSS 3440.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Not open for credit to graduate students.

description: In depth study of post-harvest requirements for specialized floral crops. Exposure to novel floral materials with an emphasis on special events and wedding designs. Mass marketing, retail price structuring and mass-production concepts are covered. Taught jointly with SAPL 530. Formerly offered as SPSS 3530.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PLSC 2520; not open for credit to graduate students.

description: Fundamentals related to horticultural specialty businesses with particular emphasis on the retail and contracting areas. Specialty and mass merchandising firms are considered and compared. Taught with SAPL 540. Formerly offered as SPSS 3540.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Not open for credit to graduate students.

course name: Urban Plant Systems Construction and Maintenance
description: Technical information on the effective construction and maintenance of planted systems. Structural and functional components of plant systems. Provision of ecosystem services. Overviews of a wide spectrum of planted systems including streetscaping, green roofs and green walls, rain gardens and bioretention, and phytoremediation systems. Techniques of soil modification. Plant selection. Establishment and maintenance of woody and herbaceous plants: planting, preservation, pruning, mulching, irrigation, and fertilization. Formerly offered as SPSS 3550.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: BIOL 1110; PLSC 2430, 3410.

description: Theory and practice in sexual and asexual propagation of horticultural plants, emphasizing the anatomical, physiological, and ecological principles involved. Laboratories provide practical experience with seeds, division, cuttings, budding, grafting, layering and tissue culture. Taught with SAPL 640. Formerly offered as SPSS 3640.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Not open for credit to graduate students.

description: Principles of field and container production of nursery stock. Emphasis on production practices for woody nursery stock from propagule to sale. Taught with SAPL 660. Formerly offered as SPSS 3660.
Introduction to greenhouse crop management with emphasis on structures, environmental control systems, and management techniques used to control crop response. Formerly offered as SPSS 3670.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PLSC 1120.

description: Greenhouse crop production techniques and methodologies. Follows a travel-course format, in which students participate in regularly scheduled field trips to commercial greenhouse operation in CT and neighboring states.  Students will make observations on the mechanical systems, management considerations, and crop production practices employed by commercial businesses. Formerly offered as SPSS 3675.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PLSC 3670, which may be taken concurrently.

description: Advanced concepts of Cannabis production, management, processing and product development that build upon SPSS 2130. Students will choose highly focused study of either indoor controlled environment production or outdoor cultivation of Cannabis for part of the course. Taught with SAPL 680. Formerly offered as SPSS 3680.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PLSC 2130 or instructor consent.

course name: Soil Management, Soil Health, and Climate Change
description: Agricultural production systems topics, including concept of soil health, measurements of soil health, carbon cycling and its impact on soil health, nitrogen cycling and its impact on soil health, nutrient management in livestock production systems, soil health and climate, plant and soil management practices impact on soil health.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: PLSC 1300 or PLSC 2120 or PLSC 3620.

description: Principles of integrated pest management covering insect, disease, and weed problems in agronomic crops, vegetables, fruits, turfgrass, ornamentals, and greenhouse production. Environmental impacts and pest control strategies will be covered. Taught with SAPL 840. Formerly offered as SPSS 3840.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Not open for credit to graduate students.

description: Students will work with professionals in an area of research or management. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory.) This course may be repeated provided that the sum total of credits earned does not exceed six credits. Formerly offered as SPSS 3990.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to juniors and seniors who have demonstrated professional potential as identified by their advisor.

description: Students are expected to submit written reports. Formerly offered as SPSS 3999.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Principles of plant physiology and gene expression from the cell to the whole  plant level. Emphasis on plant cell structure, water movement, transport systems, photosynthesis, respiration, phytohormone signals and responses to environmental stresses. Formerly offered as SPSS 4210.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: BIOL 1108 or 1110; CHEM 1122 or 1124Q or 1127Q or 1137Q or 1147Q; open to juniors or higher.

description: Major themes of political theory such as justice, obligation, and equality, and their relevance to contemporary political concerns. CA 1.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA1: Arts & Humanities

description: A survey of institutions, politics, and ideologies in democratic and non-democratic states. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA2: Social Science, CA4INT: Div & Multi - Intl

description: A survey of institutions, ideologies, development strategies, and the political processes in nonwestern culture. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA2: Social Science, CA4INT: Div & Multi - Intl

course name: Introduction to Research in Political Science
description: The process, objectives, and methods of research in political science.
The nature and problems of international politics. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA2: Social Science, CA4INT: Div & Multi - Intl

description: Analysis of the organization and operation of the American political system. CA 2.
enrollment requirements: Content Areas: CA2: Social Science

description: Introduction to research and research methods in political science.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Instructor consent.

description: Major political writings from 1900 to the present. Formerly offered as POLS 3017.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to sophomores or higher.

course name: Introduction to Government and Politics in the Middle East and North Africa
description: The politics of the contemporary Middle East. Topics may include state formation, authoritarianism, democratization, and the Arab Spring uprising. Taught in English. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: POLS 1202.

description: Chinese political structure and policymaking process, attempts at democratization, process and outcome of economic reforms, development challenges in contemporary China. Formerly offered as POLS 3245.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open only to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: a 1000-level course in Economics.

description: Developments in the presidency from President Franklin Roosevelt to the present.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: POLS 1602 and 3600.

description: The practical working of democracy and the role of state and local governments.

Exploration of the American Criminal Justice system through simulations, interactions with practitioners in the field, visits to institutions within the system, and service projects with organizations working within the system.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998W when offered as Criminal Justice in Practice.

description: Explanation of the quantitative methods used in political science. Application of these methods for the analysis of substantive political questions. Formerly offered as POLS 2072Q.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended preparation: High School Algebra II and a mathematics course.

description: Faculty-directed investigation of a research topic in political science.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Instructor consent.

course name: Variable Topics in Contemporary Political Issues
description: An exploration of contemporary political issues at the national and international levels. May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

course name: Variable Topics in Contemporary Political Issues
description: An exploration of contemporary political issues at the national and international levels. May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

description: Exploration of political theories and their relationships to contemporary popular musical genres including folk, hip-hop, pop, reggae, and rock. Students will conduct original analyses connecting political theories to contemporary popular music genres and artists.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Recommended Preparation: POLS 1002 or 3012/W. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when offered as “Political Theory and Popular Music.”

description: Survey of theories of democracy from classical times to the present; analysis of defenders and critics of democracy.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002, 3002 or 3012.

course name: Comparative Political Parties and Electoral Systems
description: A focus on political party and electoral systems around the world, including advanced industrial nations, transitional nations, and less developed nations.  Issues such as the relationship between electoral and party systems, democratic reform, voting behavior, and organization of political parties are examined.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to juniors or higher.

description: (Also offered as ENGR 3209E, HRTS 3209E.) Political, socioeconomic, environmental, science and engineering challenges of energy sources; comparison of feasibility and sustainability of energy policies around the world.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to juniors or higher.

description: (Also offered as EVST 3412.) Politics of how humans and natural systems interact. Managing the global environment, regulating resource commons, and coordinating to solve environmental problems.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to juniors or higher.

description: The role of intergovernmental and nongovernmental organizations and international law in world affairs with special attention to contemporary issues.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open to juniors or higher.

description: Lectures and films from several nations serve to illustrate techniques and effects of propaganda, analyzing the pervasive impact that propaganda has on our lives. The course concentrates on the World War II era.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to juniors or higher.

course name: Honors Core: Excavating the International in Everyday Practices
description: Examination of daily international practices utilizing an everyday objects lens, with attention to ethical implications for activism, change, and social justice.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1402.

description: Political relations between Arabs and Israelis with an emphasis on war and diplomacy.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to soph or higher. No open for credit for students who have passed SLHS 3247.

description: How children learn their first language, the effects of language on their thinking and behavior.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to sophomores or higher.

description: The analysis of speech through the application of phonetic theory.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 2156 and 2203; open to juniors or higher.

description: An introduction to the nature, causation, assessment and management of hearing impairment and the principles and techniques of public school conservation programs.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 2156 and 2203; open to juniors or higher.

description: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

description: The course, for superior students, includes independent reading, periodic conferences, and such other work as desired by the instructor.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to juniors or higher.

course name: Neuroscience of Cognitive and Communication Disorders
description: Anatomy and physiology of the central nervous system. Brain mechanisms that underlie speech, language, hearing, and cognition. Neurogenic communication disorders.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 2203 and 2204; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.

description: An introduction to the effects of hearing impairment on communication. Communication strategies for adults and children with impaired hearing are discussed.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 3248; open to juniors or higher.

description: An introduction to the effects of hearing impairment on communication. Communication strategies for adults and children with impaired hearing are discussed.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 3248; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open to juniors or higher.

course name: Introduction to Articulation, Voice, and Fluency Disorders
description: Communication problems resulting from disorders of speech, voice, and fluency. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools, hospitals, and rehabilitation centers.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 2156, 2203, 2204, and 3247; open to juniors and higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.

course name: Introduction to Language Disorders in Children
description: Development, measurement, and function of language in children. Emphasis on child language disorders and their causes. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools and private clinics.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 2204; open to juniors or higher.

course name: Introduction to Language Disorders in Children
description: Development, measurement, and function of language in children. Emphasis on child language disorders and their causes. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools and private clinics.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: SLHS 2204; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open to juniors or higher.

description: Preparation of a thesis and its presentation to the department.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011; open to junior or higher Honors students.

description: May be repeated with a change in topic.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Development and execution of student-led research projects:  Problem formulation; integration of statistics, computing, and domain knowledge; collaboration; communication; reproducibility; project management.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 3255. Not open for credit for students in the Bachelor of Science in Statistical Data Science program.

description: A standard approach to statistical analysis primarily for students of business and economics; elementary probability, sampling distributions, normal theory estimation and hypothesis testing, regression and correlation, exploratory data analysis. Learning to do statistical analysis on a personal computer is an integral part of the course.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Students can receive no more than four credits from STAT 1000Q and 1100Q. Students who have passed a 2000-level or above STAT course or who are taking such a course concurrently cannot take 1000-level STAT courses.

description: Standard and nonparametric approaches to statistical analysis; exploratory data analysis, elementary probability, sampling distributions, estimation and hypothesis testing, one- and two-sample procedures, regression and correlation. Learning to do statistical analysis on a personal computer is an integral part of the course.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Students can receive no more than four credits from STAT 1000Q and 1100Q. Students who have passed a 2000-level or above STAT course or who are taking such a course concurrently cannot take 1000-level STAT courses.

description: Analysis of variance, multiple regression, chi-square tests, and non-parametric procedures.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 1000Q or STAT 1100Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 3115Q, STAT 3215Q, or STAT 3515Q.

description: Introduction to statistical programming via Python including data types, control flow, object-oriented programming, and graphical user interface-driven applications such as Jupyter notebooks. Emphasis on algorithmic thinking, efficient implementation of different data structures, control and data abstraction, file processing, and data analysis and visualization.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: MATH 1132Q, or instructor consent. Recommended preparation: CSE 1010 or prior programming experience. Not open to students who have passed CSE 2050 or 2500 or ECON 3322 or 5322.

description: Basic probability distributions, point and interval estimation, tests of hypotheses, correlation and regression, analysis of variance, experimental design, non-parametric procedures.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: MATH 1132Q or 1152Q; students may not receive more than three credits from STAT 3025 and 3345. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 3115Q, 3215Q, 3515Q, 4190 or 4625.

description: Straight-line regression, multiple regression, regression diagnostics, transformations, dummy variables, one-way and two-way analysis of variance, analysis of covariance, stepwise regression.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 2215Q or 3025Q or instructor consent. Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 3215Q or 5315.

description: Introduction to data science for effectively storing, processing, analyzing and making inferences from data. Topics include project management, data preparation, data visualization, statistical models, machine learning, distributed computing, and ethics.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: MATH 1132Q, STAT 2255 or COGS 2500Q or ECON 3322, STAT 3115Q or 3215Q, or instructor consent

description: Probability set functions, random variables, expectations, moment generating functions, discrete and continuous random variables, joint and conditional distributions, multinomial distribution, bivariate normal distribution, functions of random variables, central limit theorms, computer simulation of probability models.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: MATH 2110Q or 2130Q. Students may not receive more than three credits from STAT 3025Q and 3345Q, or from STAT 3345Q and 3375Q.

description: The mathematical theory underlying statistical methods. Probability spaces, distributions in one and several dimensions, generating functions, and limit theorems.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: A grade of C+ or better in MATH 2110Q or 2130Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 3345Q or 5585. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 3445Q.

description: Sampling distributions and parameter estimation. Neyman-Pearson theory of hypothesis testing, correlation, regression, analysis of variance.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 3375Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 5685. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 4875.

description: The student will attend 6-8 seminars per semester, and choose one statistical topic to investigate in detail. The student will write a well-revised, comprehensive paper on this topic, including a literature review, description of technical details, and a summary and discussion.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 2215Q or 3115Q; STAT 3025Q or 3375Q; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011.

description: Methods of designing experiments utilizing regression analysis and the analysis of variance.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 2215Q or 3025Q or instructor consent. Credits may not be received for both STAT 3515Q and BIST/STAT 5515.

description: Introduction to computing for statistical problems; obtaining features of distributions, fitting models and implementing inference (obtaining confidence intervals and running hypothesis tests); simulation-based approaches and basic numerical methods. One hour per week devoted to computing and programming skills.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 3025Q or 3375Q. Recommended preparation: an applied statistics course.

description: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

description: Supervised research in probability or statistics. A final written report and oral presentation are required.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: Introduction to prediction using time-series regression methods with non-seasonal and seasonal data. Smoothing methods for forecasting. Modeling and forecasting using univariate, autoregressive, moving average models.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 3445.

description: Capstone course in data science. Real-world statistical data science in practice: problem formulation; integration of statistics, computing, and domain knowledge; collaboration; communication; reproducibility; project management.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 3255; STAT 3025Q or 3375Q or MATH 3160 or instructor consent. Corequisite: STAT 4916W. Open only to Statistical Data Science majors.

description: The course is a companion course to STAT 4915, which must be taken concurrently. Students will write a well-revised and comprehensive paper on their STAT 4915 course project, including literature review, description of technical details, reproducible statistical and data scientific analyses, and discussion of results.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: STAT 3255; STAT 3025Q or 3375Q or MATH 3160 or instructor consent; ENGL 1007 or 1010 or 1011. Corequisite: STAT 4915 must be taken concurrently with STAT 4916W or instructor consent.

description: Introduction to the practical aspects of literary translation with a focus on translating different types of literary texts into English. Working knowledge of a language other than English required.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Working knowledge of a language other than English required.

description: Developing research ideas into fundable, discipline-appropriate research applications. Topics may include drafting and revision of statements; meeting compliance requirements; budgeting; completing a literature review; creating a timeline; and practicing interview skills. Culminates in proposal for Holster Scholars Program. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
An overview of the university experience with a focus on acquiring learning skills and understanding resources available for academic success.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

description: An overview of topics relevant to the theme of the Learning Community.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

description: Guided research or reading, discussion, and writing on topics of professional interest to the instructor. Course materials promote independent learning and active engagement in the academic life of the university. May be repeated for credit with a change in content.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

description: Activities, discussions, and critical reflections related to service-learning, community engagement, and/or experiential learning activities specific to the theme of a learning community.  Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). This course may be repeated for a total of four semesters with change of activity and/or skill level.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for a total of 4 credits

description: Supervised fieldwork of six to eight hours per week (for a minimum of 80 hours) for 8-10 weeks, relevant to major and/or career goals. Mid semester and final evaluations are prepared by the field supervisor and the course instructor. This course does not fill any general education or major requirements. Formerly offered as UNIV 1991.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to matriculated undergraduates only, students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students must secure a satisfactory internship position prior to the end of the second week of the semester of enrollment in this course. May be repeated one time, with permission. Open to matriculated undergraduates only, students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students must secure a satisfactory internship position prior to the end of the second week of the semester of enrollment in this course.

description: Supervised fieldwork of 8-10 hours per week for 8-12 weeks for a minimum of 80 hours at the internship site. Evaluations by the field supervisor and the course instructor. Students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students must secure a satisfactory internship position prior to the end of the second week of the semester. May be repeated one time, with permission. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for a total of 0 credits

description: Introduction to disciplinarity, multidisciplinarity, and interdisciplinarity. Recommended for students exploring an application to the Individualized Major Program.

An interdisciplinary seminar designed for honors students and open to other qualified students. Topics vary from semester to semester. May be repeated  for credit with change of topic. Sponsored by the Honors Program.
enrollment requirements: May be repeated for credit

description: A variable topics course designed to help students engage with the advanced academic and enrichment opportunities unique to their learning community. This course is only open to sophomores, juniors, or seniors in learning communities.
enrollment requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Open to sophomores, juniors, or seniors in learning communities.

description: With a change in topic; may be repeated for credit.
